I saw this and I laughed really hard. If you don’t know today was international pronouns day today and all the libraries were handing out free pronouns buttons. But leave it to men to assume they are society’s default idk I still just think this is super funny like guys either assumed they didn’t need to wear one of these because they’re a MAN and don’t see this stuff as important or applicable to them or they’re so deeply wrapped up in toxic masculinity they would never pick up a rainbow pin and idk I think it’s super sad but leaving the library tonight at midnight it was just really funny to me. I’m about to put a nicer thing in <#CFDQBKRJM|inclusivity>
this was walt borland he devotes the entire first week of his classes bragging about his history as an entrepreneur and how successful he is
*fuck
Also yeah idk if he would have said this to a male student. The duck
Me telling you you’re too sensitive doesn’t give me anything actionable to do to improve the situation. Instead, I should ask what I can do to improve this situation
Also WE TALK ABOUT THIS ALL THE TIME IN ETC - telling someone they’re too sensitive literally NEVER helps a situation. Because it takes all the actionable accountability off the person saying it
Is there some higher up you can go to about this? Because it definitely feels personal and you shouldn’t feel uncomfortable being SUMMONED for this confrontation!
<@U7C661T32> thats real af!! I hate that narrative bc it makes me feel like if I'm not stressed and/or suffering i'm not doing good work and that just sux & contributes to impostor syndrome :-1:

I think that it is absolutely inappropriate for him to tell you that you are being too sensitive. It shouldn't matter what your identity is; your perspective as a student with real life experiences is still valid, especially if it is for a course evaluation where they ASK for your opinions. I think it would be really great if you are able to meet with him and find some common ground. Maybe he is just ignorant and needs to hear more about your experiences as a student in STEM? This really made me upset. professors should be trained in cultural sensitivity and navigating students' feelings and opinions...
Like idk wtf am I supposed to do I feel like it’d be so uncomfy to meet with him now and probably not productive

In one of my classes we write course reflections and we can submit 3 per month and I wrote one about how you don’t need to put down stem majors to show liberal arts ones are good because that seems to be a recurring theme that he talks about and this was his response to me. He wrote more he wants to meet now
WTF
I CANNOT BELIEVE THIS
WAIT WAIT WAIT
Do you think he would’ve said this to a male student?

Yooo my friends and I have been talking a lot about this difference in culture between artists too. Some of them are like: “SUFFER FOR YOUR ART” and others are like: “FAM GET THAT GOOD SLEEP AND TAKE CARE OF YOUR BODY” and one of those def makes me want to make more work than the other XD

And he kept being like “this is the CULTURE OF INNOVATION” and I was like.... nah fam I’d rather like get 8 hrs of sleep and think creatively without depriving myself of a healthy lifestyle :woman-shrugging::skin-tone-2:

idk I would just much rather attend something like that than have it be like “we feed you PIZZA and CAFFEINE and we LOCK YOU IN A ROOM for TWO DAYS” and I do my best work when I’m relaxed and happy :) and at this hackathon I went to there was a p high ranking exec that was like bragging abt their Mountain Dew pizza things and it rubbed me the wrong way

Has anyone ever thot about doing a healthy hackathon? Like similar to a normal hackathon except they encourage you to drink water and eat good food and take breaks/naps? And maybe there’s essential oil diffusers and face masks or something? Putting this in the ktphemales because I feel like traditional hackathons like discourage basic hygiene and the “Mountain Dew and Doritos” diet is generally associated w the hyper masculine hacker bros archetype...

It’s interesting because randomly switching pronouns is a technique to try to break those expectations BUT there’s a whole other school of thought that says you should just always use the pronoun of the less represented group to fight it instead
Male :clap::skin-tone-4: pilots :clap::skin-tone-4: crash :clap::skin-tone-4: planes :clap::skin-tone-4:
yeah!!!

we’ve done that a couple times in my ws classes like we read a study about how from a young age it’s kind of taught that certain jobs are gendered like nurses are women pilots are men and then it got even worse because when they did a survey it was always white people and no one ever pictured people of color it was wild
but it was just … i was like fuck! i’m all about women being professors but my initial idea of a professor is still male it made me kind of upset at myself

that being said its easy for me to shake off because its a really common thing for people to say

right so I agree with all of that.  its a weird connection to make between praising someone for something they did and then immediately implying that a) *that* is what makes them dateable (annoying to shank), and b) that people should consider dating him because of this fact (annoying to others).  it puts the emphasis on the wrong thing.

This is totally me reading into what that phrase itself means, and the way in which it is used, and who uses it because it’s not a weird thing to them to use - mostly because that’s all I’ve been doing in my theory classes this semester XD

Lol this is gonna sound very performance art / ETC, but it felt like a performance of heterosexuality and masculinity? In this really offhand way, which made me think about all the identities of mine I can’t perform in that offhand way, necessarily. ¯\_(ツ)_/¯ and I think that was mostly because I’ve never used that phrase, even in the flip side. When I’m hyping up the ladies of my life it’s always: “LOOK HOW AMAZING SHE IS AND ALL THE AMAZING STUFF SHE DOES” but I never want to translate that into “AND THEREFORE YOU SHOULD DATE HER” because that feels like such an invalidation of her work, just because of all the past power systems related to heterosexual relationships and ideas of ownership in them. Does that make sense?
what are u feeling about it <@U7C661T32> ?
but i don’t think it’s like problematic, just a little bit of a weird thing to say
lol i screenshotted that and sent it to someone (cuz i’m a snake) it also struck me as kinda weird
truthfully, i didn’t think anything of it

ugh i feel strong imposter syndrome that I only got my job because i'm a woman and the point of my internship was to hire minorities, so now i feel underqualified compared to people who "regular' interview for the role. I know that's wrong but I think about it all the time!
Confidence is key so do whatever makes you feel more comfy!
Me!

i think there are ways that diversity programs can be really amazing. like the program i was in this summer was specially made to educate and encourage historically misrepresented groups and then bring them in as juniors as regular interns. i felt like this program really was a great foot in the door. at the same time, quotas and diversity hires, especially when they are so up front about it, make me feel like i have no worth!! and that is the wrong way to go about it.
i hate when this happens!! like the opportunities im given are only because im a girl??? like thats all i have going for me??? maybe im actually talented lol like what if???
I like the way I look in blouses better so I usually do that
I think either is fine! I’ve worn a white blouse under my blazer and it still looks professional
Hello ladies, when you are dressing business professional for an important interview, do you recommend wearing a collared dress shirt under your suit jacket or a nice blouse or is either fine?
SHE LITERALLY EXPLICITLY SAID THAT ALSFKDJLDSKFJ LIEK I WAS LIKE … WHY ARE U TELLING ME THIS IS IT SUPPOSED TO MAKE ME FEEL GOOD
DUDE I KNOW I ALFDLASKFLKAJF
<@U94T3M9EX> I think as well!

the whole aspect of diversity hires (for me, gender) has been very very frustrating for me.  not only is it something that most of us worry about that leads to imposter syndrome but it is SO often reinforced by situations like this or friends telling us not to worry about a bad interview, it’s fine, we’ll get the job because we are women. FUCKK all of that
squad up !! let’s meet up for sure
did u mean FACK
omg “we go aBoVe AnD bEyOnD and hire THREE women” FUCK YOU

dude I feel that... first of all that's so shitty that they overtly tokenized you for that role.... you _could_ give her benefit of the doubt on the microaggressions but I feel like it's a red flag if she literally explicitly said "two women and two people of different ethnicities", that seems extremely inappropriate to me. at the same time in my experience, I'm like, if I get this job because of my "diverse" identities, it's still a job opportunity and an advantage that _kind of_ makes up for other types of under representation. With that being said, there is a right and wrong way to do diversity recruiting and I feel like this company was helllla wrong. But one thing is for sure, you don't need to feel guilty about it, there's def some white cis dude out there who would gladly take a diversity hire if he had the chance.
but literally you could have seen that if you’d looked at my resume
which makes me ineligible for the job because they need someone right now immediately
I also don’t know if she really looked at my resume?? because she asked me when I was graduating and i was like spring 2020
i’m also torn because I almost wish I would have said something but i was kind of so stunned that i kept on repeating “haha that’s great to hear!!! ”
so i guess i just want to ask or hear your thoughts on companies diversity initiatives and how they can come off as tokenizing

maybe this belongs in inclusivity but im putting this here because it kind of goes along w the article jules just posted — I talked to some of u about this but i just had an interview this morning where the recruiter repeatedly mentioned how much the ceo valued diversity and then went on to say something along the lines of “we’re mandated (but we go above and beyond!!!) to consider two women and two people of different ethnicities for every position!!!”
she also kept on repeating “U have an interesting background” but by the end of the interview im not sure if she was referring to my actual background and resume or just the fact that I’m not white
<@U7EKJT35Y> will know

<@UD6QW5E10> is!

more ktphemales dialogues???

I also found that often those events rely heavily on women taking on the role of making it happen, running the event, helping spread the word, etc. (something similar seems to happen in regards to Pride events too)

thank u for sharing juliet! i think the quote u included from the article really pinpoints the issue at an institutional level — corporations r willing to host more diversity events to make underrep communities feel more included, but these sorts of events (1) happen very infrequently, most likely on a yearly basis, and come off as a solution to the issue, even tho  they’re just temporary fixes and thus (2) do not solve the root cause of discriminating against women in the workplace. institutional change is no doubt hard and long and difficult, but it would at least be nice to see companies changing their attitudes toward women to be one that is inclusive AND long-standing, not something that just comes out once a year at a singular “women’s day event”

"Google systematically pays women less than men doing similar work, according to a class action-lawsuit accusing the technology company of denying promotions and career opportunities to qualified women who are “segregated” into lower-paying jobs."
another article that is linked in this one...<https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2017/sep/14/google-women-promotions-lower-paying-jobs-lawsuit>

attachments.text: Exclusive: Women say Google denied them promotions, telling the Guardian they were forced into less prestigious jobs despite qualifications

messages.text: "I am really sick of diversity programs I encountered that are corporate cheerleading and totally unwilling to do the hard work it would actually take to make this a better industry for women."
